text.p: Here is how major stock markets outside the United States ended on Thursday.

LONDON - A weak opening on Wall Street dragged UK stocks of their day's highs by the close on Thursday after a day in which the market continued to be gripped by nervousness following the share losses of recent sessions. After rising 27 points at one stage, the FTSE 100 closed just 8.2 points higher at 3,990.7.

FRANKFURT - German share index closes slightly firmer but off session highs and eye U.S. market moves for direction this afternoon. Market still trading in expected range between 2,820 and 2,860 points. Dollar still helping underpin the market. The 30-share DAX index closed up 6.03 points at 2,847.08. In post-bourse trade the index was up 10.58 at 2,846.94.
PARIS - French stocks closed slightly lower on Thursday after a cautious day of moderate trading. The blue-chip CAC-40 index closed down 1.17 points or 0.05 percent at 2,212.11.

ZURICH - Swiss shares closed a cautious session little change, overshadowed by widespread concerns about further developments on global financials markets. The all-share Swiss Performance Index (SPI) closed 0.38 points, or 0.02 percent, higher at 2,465.23.

TOKYO - Tokyo stocks ended feebly on Thursday but well off their lows as cautious market participants waited for the December futures and options settlement on Friday, brokers said. They said Wall Street's sharp sell-off overnight dampened sentiment. The Nikkei 225 closed at 20,501.20, down 67.18 points or 0.33 percent.

HONG KONG - Hong Kong stocks closed down on Thursday, with investors nervously consolidating gains of recent months. "The market opened nervous and confused, partly because of to the decline in the U.S., and partly due to the technical glitch," said Claire Burges Watson in institutional sales at Kim Eng Securities. The Hang Seng Index closed down 136.32 points at 13,053.28.

SYDNEY - The Australian share market closed lower on Thursday as local investors ignored positive employment data and followed their nervous U.S. counterparts out of equities. The All Ordinaries index lost 19.7 points to close at 2,339.6.

JOHANNESBURG - Thwarting pre-Christmas holiday fever, South African shares set new record turnover on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange of 1.07 billion rand, including a large overnight asset swap. Industrials ended 37.1 points down at 7,814.7, all-shares were off 32.1 at 6,607 and golds dipped 8.9 to 1,533.2.
